Eluding Secure Aggregation in Federated Learning
via Model Inconsistency

Dario Pasquini dario.pasquini@epfl.ch SPRING Lab, EPFLLausanneSwitzerland ,Â  Danilo Francati dfrancati@cs.au.dk Aarhus UniversityAarhusDenmark Â andÂ  Giuseppe Ateniese ateniese@gmu.edu George Mason UniversityFairfax, VirginiaUSA
Abstract.

Secure aggregation is a cryptographic protocol that securely computes the aggregation of its inputs. It is pivotal in keeping model updates private in federated learning. Indeed, the use of secure aggregation prevents the server from learning the value and the source of the individual model updates provided by the users, hampering inference and data attribution attacks.

In this work, we show that a malicious server can easily elude secure aggregation as if the latter were not in place. We devise two different attacks capable of inferring information on individual private training datasets, independently of the number of users participating in the secure aggregation. This makes them concrete threats in large-scale, real-world federated learning applications.

The attacks are generic and equally effective regardless of the secure aggregation protocol used. They exploit a vulnerability of the federated learning protocol caused by incorrect usage of secure aggregation and lack of parameter validation. Our work demonstrates that current implementations of federated learning with secure aggregation offer only a â€œfalse sense of securityâ€.

Federated Learning, Secure Aggregation, Model Inconsistency

1. Introduction

Deep learning is evolving rapidly but often at the expense of privacy and security. Neural networks may misbehave, hide backdoors, or be reverse-engineered to reveal sensitive information about the training datasetsÂ (Ateniese etÂ al., 2015; Shokri etÂ al., 2017; Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015). Data holders are thus reluctant to provide and share their datasets unless some level of protection is in place.

Cryptographic primitives, such as multi-party computation (MPC) and fully homomorphic encryption (FHE), offer only a partial solution to this problem: They enable learning while protecting sensitive information but at the expense of efficiency and scalability. Even state-of-the-art implementations of these primitives are highly inefficient and add a significant overhead to the learning process, making them unusable and inapplicable in practice.

Accordingly, researchers have looked at alternative solutions that rely on decentralization, where data remain local with the participants while the neural network evolves during the distributed learning process. Along this line of research, federated learning (FL)Â (KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016, 2017; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019), along with its main implementations federated stochastic gradient descent (FedSGD) and federated averaging (FedAVG), has been proposed. At a high level, FL allows a set of users to train a shared neural network without outsourcing their local datasets. To this end, they are only required to locally train the neural network and send model updates (e.g., gradients, model parameters) to a central server. The updates will be aggregated by the server, completing a round of the training. The informal security guarantee offered by FL is that sharing the (possibly scrambledÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016)) updates does not leak any information about the actual training instances used by the users. Unfortunately, it has been shown that an adversary can invert an individual model update of a target user in order to leak a large amount of information about its datasetÂ (Hitaj etÂ al., 2017; Nasr etÂ al., 2019; Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Melis etÂ al., 2019).

For this reason, Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) have proposed to combine secure aggregation (SA) protocols with FL as a first step to increase the security of FL, preventing the server from accessing individual model updates. Informally, SA is a specialized MPC protocol that allows a set of users to compute the sum of their private inputs securely. The security guarantee is the same as standard MPC protocols, i.e., nothing is leaked about the inputs except what can be inferred from the output (the sum of the values).

SA is believed to be one of the most robust defenses against gradient inversion and related inference attacksÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2021). In particular, the application of SA in FL has two main objectives: (1)Â â€œPrivacy by aggregationâ€:Â Aggregating together a suitable number of model updates smooths out the information carried out by individual contributions. In turn, this makes it unfeasible to assert or recover meaningful information on individual training instances that produced the aggregated value. (2)Â â€œPrivacy by shufflingâ€:Â SA â€œhidesâ€ the source of the aggregated information; even if sensitive data is recovered from the aggregated model updates, this cannot be attributed to the user (the individual model update) who provided it. Thus, although the privacy of the set of users may be violated, the privacy of individuals is preserved.

Our work shows that a motivated and malicious server can easily violate both of these fundamental properties of current SA defenses. This vulnerability emerges from the federated learning protocol, not the SA protocol; it is caused by incorrect usage of the SA protocol. For example, even if we abstract the SA protocol with an ideal aggregation functionality, the protocol is still exploitable. In this case, the failure to validate SA inputs by the user is one of the protocolâ€™s weaknesses, and we are not targeting a specific implementation of SA. The main intuition is that model updates (i.e., the inputs of SA) are under the indirect control of the malicious server since model updates are computed starting from the parameters sent by the server. A malicious server can leverage this control to tamper with the updates (that are the inputs of SA) so that their aggregation will leak information about the update of a target user.

In order to achieve this, the server exploits a new attack vector that we call model inconsistency. Here, the server distributes different views of the same model to different users within the same round. In this work, we show that model inconsistency can introduce new vulnerabilities in FL algorithms. The intuition is that a malicious server, providing different parameters to different users, can exploit behavioral differences in the model updates provided by the different models to infer information on usersâ€™ datasets, even when those model updates are securely aggregated before reaching the server.

To make this inherent vulnerability evident, we implement two attacks that give a representative view of the threat induced by the model inconsistency attack vector. Eventually, these attacks demonstrate how a malicious server can nullify the security offered by current SA-based defenses proposed for FL. That is: (1)Â individual model updates can be perfectly recovered from the final aggregated value, independently of the number of users participating in the aggregation, and, (2)Â the source of the recovered data can be attributed to individuals in the pool of active users.

Finally, we introduce multiple strategies for preventing the vulnerability that was brought up. The proposed solutions seamlessly integrate with current state-of-the-art SA protocols without impacting performance or utility.

1.1. Contributions

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

Model inconsistency

We demonstrate that FL incorrectly leverages SAÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), and as a result, it is as secure as the original FL protocol (without SA). The combination of the above two observations implies that Sğ‘†S could act maliciously and craft different parameters for different users in order to tamper with the inputs of SA. As our two attacks will demonstrate, at a different scale, Sğ‘†S can exclude from the aggregation the updates of some non-target users ğ’°âˆ–{uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—}ğ’°subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\}, forcing the SA to leak part of the model update Î”ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—Î˜subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of the targetÂ uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}}.

InÂ SectionÂ 5, we present a first attack, named gradient suppression. The output will be equal to the gradient Î”ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—Î˜subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of the latter user uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This is the first practical attack that demonstrates that a malicious server can completely nullify SA. More importantly, the attack does not require auxiliary information on the targets, e.g., the distribution of usersâ€™ datasets, or unrealistic architecture alterations.

Canary-gradient attack

We extend the first attack and devise a second approach called canary-gradient. Here, we show that a malicious server Sğ‘†S can modify the targetâ€™s model to induce specific behavior in the derivative of a tiny subset Î¾ğœ‰\xi of its parameters (e.g.,Â two out of millions of parameters). In particular, Sğ‘†S can forge malicious parameters that force the model to produce non-zero gradients for Î¾ğœ‰\xi only when a specific adversarially-chosen property is present in the input batch used to compute the update. Then, the server can preserve the targetâ€™s gradient for Î¾ğœ‰\xi in the final aggregated value by forcing the non-target users to unconditionally produce zero gradients only for the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi. This allows Sğ‘†S to recover the targetâ€™s gradient for Î¾ğœ‰\xi in â€œplaintextâ€ and ascertain the presence of the queried property in the userâ€™s private data (e.g.,Â membership inference). Eventually, this demonstrates that a malicious server can cast extremely effective property inference attacks on individual users under SA, while ensuring the stealthiness of the attack.

The (in)correct usage of SA in FL

In cryptographic terms, SA protocols are specialized multi-party computation (MPC) protocols that implement the ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºâ€‹(v1,â€¦,vn)=âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°vi=vsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’°subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘£f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i}=v. They are built assuming that the inputs of honest users are untamperable, i.e., an adversary has no control over the input visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} of an honest user uiâˆˆğ’°subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’°u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}. This holds in both the semi-honest and malicious security models.

Unfortunately, the above assumption does not hold in FL. As discussed earlier, a malicious server Sğ‘†S can tamper with the inputs (v1,â€¦,vn)subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}) of the honest users ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}. Unlike other attacks, ours is the first that does not contradict the security of the underlying SA protocol and does not require auxiliary information about user data. Our attacks will succeed regardless of the number of FL protocol users, which is additional evidence that SA and FL cannot protect against adversarial servers.

Preventing model inconsistency.

We discuss ways to help mitigate model inconsistency by integrating consistency checks during the FL protocol. In particular, we show that the two most influential SA protocols of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) (CCSâ€™17) and Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020) (CCSâ€™20) can be modified to incorporate consistency checks without affecting the efficiency of the original FL protocol. This is achieved by linking SAâ€™s masking values (generated by a particular user to hide its input) to the parameters received from the server. By doing it this way, when two or more users receive different parameters, their masks will look random. As a result, the malicious server cannot tell whose input is whose, reducing the attack efficacy.

Finally, we will discuss how DP techniques can be used in conjunction with SA, which remains a suitable solution to prevent a malicious server from breaching usersâ€™ privacy. We refer the reader toÂ SectionÂ 7 for more details.

To make our results reproducible, we made our code available.111https://github.com/pasquini-dario/EludingSecureAggregation.

2. Related Work

2.1. Federated learning and secure aggregation

The distributed architecture of FL protocolÂ (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) provides a fertile ground for attackersÂ (Hitaj etÂ al., 2017; Melis etÂ al., 2019; Nasr etÂ al., 2019; Fang etÂ al., 2020). This is because a malicious party, mainly the server, has access to sensitive information such as model updates that can be exploited to violate usersâ€™ privacy. Accordingly, SA has been proposed by Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) as a fundamental step to increase the security of FL without modifying the original structure of the protocol. Subsequent works focus on the development of new SA protocols for FL with reduced communication/computation overheadÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020; Choi etÂ al., 2020; Guo etÂ al., 2020; Kadhe etÂ al., 2020; So etÂ al., 2021b), multiple serversÂ (Beguier and Tramel, 2020), increased robustness against malicious updatesÂ (Pillutla etÂ al., 2019; Burkhalter etÂ al., 2021), or with verifiable aggregationÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2019b; Guo etÂ al., 2020).222In FL with verifiable aggregationsÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2019b; Guo etÂ al., 2020), users are supposed to verify the integrity of the aggregated model updates and compute the new parameters (if the parameters are updated solely by the server, then the verifiability of aggregated gradients becomes meaningless). This differs from the original FL protocolÂ (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) in which the server updates the model for improved scalability.

Separately, several other works focused on building new protocols (or propose significant modifications of FL, e.g., protocol, architecture, etc.) to train a deep neural network without leaking unnecessary information about the datasets of the users. We refer the reader toÂ AppendixÂ A for more details.

2.2. Gradient Inversion

A core privacy concern in FL is the role of the server. In this direction, it has been shown that, without SA, even a semi-honest server can invert usersâ€™ gradients (sent as a model update in a particular round of FL) and compute a close-enough approximation of usersâ€™ local training datasets. In a nutshell, by leveraging fÎ˜subscriptğ‘“Î˜f_{\Theta} (where Î˜Î˜\Theta are the parameters of the current round of FL) and the gradient locally computed by the user uğ‘¢u using a subset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} of its local data, the server can recover ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} by searching a set of instances ğ’Ÿ^^ğ’Ÿ\widehat{\mathcal{D}} that generates the gradient similar to the one sent by the user. Thanks to the inherent smoothness of the neural network fÎ˜subscriptğ‘“Î˜f_{\Theta}, this searching problem can be defined as a second-order optimization, i.e.,

(1) argminğ’Ÿ^â€‹[dâ€‹(âˆ‡ğ’Ÿ^Î˜,âˆ‡ğ’ŸÎ˜)â‹…Î±â€‹râ€‹(ğ’Ÿ^)]subscriptargmin^ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]â‹…ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡Î˜^ğ’Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡Î˜ğ’Ÿğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ^ğ’Ÿ\text{argmin}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}}[d(\nabla^{\Theta}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}},\nabla^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}})\cdot\alpha r(\widehat{\mathcal{D}})]

where ğ’Ÿ^^ğ’Ÿ\widehat{\mathcal{D}} is the candidate solution of the malicious serverÂ Sğ‘†S, dğ‘‘dÂ is a distance function to measure the discrepancy between the gradient signals âˆ‡ğ’Ÿ^Î˜subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡Î˜^ğ’Ÿ\nabla^{\Theta}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}} and âˆ‡ğ’ŸÎ˜subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡Î˜ğ’Ÿ\nabla^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}}, rğ‘Ÿr is a regularizer defined on the input domain, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the weight associated to the regularization term in the optimization. In the work of ZhuÂ etÂ al.Â (Zhu etÂ al., 2019), dğ‘‘d is set to be the Euclidean distance, and the L-BFGS solver is used to solve the optimization problem. The follow-up work of GeipingÂ etÂ al.Â (Geiping etÂ al., 2020) improves their approach/results by noting that the gradient signal is scale-invariant and accounts for that in defining the optimization objective inÂ EquationÂ 1. Their work improves the effectiveness of the inversion attack, drastically increasing its applicability on real-world architectures such as ResNetsÂ (He etÂ al., 2016) and more realistic batch sizes and a number of FedAVG local iterations. These results have been further improved in the work of YinÂ etÂ al.Â (Yin etÂ al., 2021) by relying on additional regularization terms and tailored optimization techniques.

A more recent line of research dispensed with optimization-based approaches to focus on closed-form procedures to recover data from gradients in deep neural networksÂ (Zhu and Blaschko, 2020; Pan etÂ al., 2020). In this vein, a recent work of FowlÂ etÂ al.Â (Fowl etÂ al., 2021) (which is concurrent to our work) improves over previous approaches by considering a malicious server that modifies the FL architecture and crafts the network parameters to artificially create a neural layer that retains information on the input batch. In particular, this is a linear layer followed by a ReLUÂ activation whose parameters must be chosen considering the private setsâ€™ CDF for a given property, i.e., the attacker must have some auxiliary information on usersâ€™ training datasets. Unfortunately, this extra knowledge may not be acquired in realistic scenarios (when usersâ€™ data distributions are unknown) and weakens the applicability of the attack. In addition, the server needs to manipulate the model architecture and place a linear layer at the start of the network to maximize the attack effectiveness. However, this modification is unworkable for typical deep learning applications (e.g.,Â in computer vision).

LamÂ etÂ al.Â (Lam etÂ al., 2021) showed that, if SA is enabled, a malicious server Sğ‘†S can still try to reconstruct individual contributions by observing multiple training rounds of FL. This disaggregation process can be reduced to a matrix factorization problem. However, their attack is effective only in a particular restricted setting in which the malicious server Sğ‘†S (i)ğ‘–(i) alters the protocol execution by providing always the same parameters Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} at each round of FL (i.e., users compute their gradient updates always on the same model fÎ˜~subscriptğ‘“~Î˜f_{\widetilde{\Theta}}), (iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–(ii) leverages additional side-channel information about usersâ€™ participation in the training rounds, and (iâ€‹iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–(iii) users are required to use the same local training dataset at each round of FL. Their approach enables the gradient inversion attack ofÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021) to scale and be effective in more realistic scenarios where there is a significant number of users participating in the protocol execution of FL. Nevertheless, its feasibility still depends on the number of active users, network parameters, and other factors such as the number of rounds that the server monitors to recover individual gradients accurately. Additionally, while the authors showed that this approach could handle noise, its applicability is inherently limited in FedSGD, where local training is performed on randomly selected batches rather than the entire, static, local dataset. Finally, this attack is not applicable in large-scale, real-world deployments of FLÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2019; Yang etÂ al., 2018), where users participate in the protocol only once with a high probability.

3.2. Federated learning

Federated learning (FL) allows a set of users ğ’°={u1,â€¦,un}ğ’°subscriptğ‘¢1â€¦subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›\mathcal{U}\leavevmode\nobreak\ =\leavevmode\nobreak\ \{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\}, where each uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} holds a local training dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, to train the deep neural network fÎ˜:ğ’³â†’ğ’´:subscriptğ‘“Î˜â†’ğ’³ğ’´f_{\Theta}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} on a global dataset that is distributed amongÂ ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}. The learning phase of FL is an interactive process that is divided into rounds. In the setting of FL, we denote with tğ‘¡t the current round of FL and we use the superscript â€œ(t)â€ (sometimes in combination with the subscript â€œiâ€) to denote values used or generated (such as batches, model updates, model parameters) during the current round tğ‘¡t (by a particular user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}). FedSGD and FedAVG

3.3. Secure aggregation

A secure aggregation (SA) protocol is a specialized multi-party computation (MPC) protocol that allows a set of users to compute the summation (a.k.a. aggregation) of their inputs. Let ğ’°={u1,â€¦,un}ğ’°subscriptğ‘¢1â€¦subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›\mathcal{U}=\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\} be a set of users, each holding a secret input visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} (e.g., integer, group element, vector). A protocol Î Î \Pi is a secure SA protocol if it securely implements the following ideal functionality:

(5) fğ—Œğ–ºâ€‹(v1,â€¦,vn)=(v,â€¦,v)forÂ â€‹v=âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°vi,formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›ğ‘£â€¦ğ‘£forÂ ğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’°subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})=(v,\ldots,v)\quad\text{for }v=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i},

i.e., a trusted third party executes fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}} computes and returns to all users ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U} the aggregation vğ‘£v of the usersâ€™ inputs (v1,â€¦,vn)subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}). Informally, a SA protocol Î Î \Pi is considered secure if it is at least as secure as invoking the ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}}. This is formalized using the standard ideal and real-world paradigm of MPCÂ (Cramer and DamgÃ¥rd, 2005) (seeÂ AppendixÂ B). The security of Î Î \Pi does not guarantee that nothing is leaked about other usersâ€™ inputs. Instead, it implies that nothing is leaked except what can be inferred from the final aggregation. The information that can be inferred is highly correlated to the inputs provided to fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}} (e.g., entropy).

To increase the security of FL and mitigate attacks such as gradient inversion (seeÂ SectionÂ 2), Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) propose a communication-efficient, dropout resilient SA for FL.555InÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) the aggregation vğ‘£v is obtained by the server Sğ‘†S only. This can be represented as an ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºâ€‹(v1,â€¦,vn,âŠ¥)=(âŠ¥,â€¦,âŠ¥,v)superscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›bottombottomâ€¦bottomğ‘£f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n},\bot)=(\bot,\ldots,\bot,v) where the (n+1)ğ‘›1(n+1)-th input/output is associated to the server Sğ‘†S and âŠ¥bottom\bot represents the empty string. When applied to FL, the protocol guarantees a secure aggregation of usersâ€™ model updates â€“ sensitive values that carry important information about the usersâ€™ datasets. Hence, an adversary (e.g., malicious user or server) can not observe the individual model update Î”ğ’Ÿi(t)Î˜(t)subscriptsuperscriptÎ”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} of a target user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}. This decreases the amount of information about the local training dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} of the target user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} that an adversary can leak (e.g., by performing gradient inversion attacks). We stress that SA protocolsÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) have the property of being robust: The final aggregation can always be computed when at most Î´ğ›¿\delta users drop out during the execution of the SA protocol (i.e., more than nâˆ’Î´ğ‘›ğ›¿n-\delta users are online). When this condition is failed (i.e., the online users are less than nâˆ’Î´ğ‘›ğ›¿n-\delta), the server cannot recover the final aggregated value. Hence, SA also guarantees that the server can only see the final aggregation when the latter contains at least nâˆ’Î´ğ‘›ğ›¿n-\delta model updates (ensuring the desired level of â€œprivacy by aggregationâ€).

Both Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020) (the most influential SA protocols in the literature) demonstrate the security of their protocols in both the semi-honest and malicious models (including collusion between server and users)Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Theorems 6.2 and 6.6) andÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020, Theorems 3.6 and 4.9). However, we emphasize that the results inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) cover only the security of the SA protocol. Nothing is claimed about the security of the overall FL protocol with SA enabled.

4. Threat model

In this section we formalize the threat model in which our attacks are defined (SectionÂ 5 and SectionÂ 6). We adopt the exact same threat model for which the SA protocols of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Section 6.2) (CCS â€™17) and Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020, Section 4) (CCS â€™20) have been demonstrated to be secure: A malicious parameter server (aggregator) that can corrupt at most a fixed number mğ‘šm (out of nğ‘›n) of users.666The number of corrupted users mğ‘šm depends on the implementation of the SA protocol. For instance, this is âŒˆn3âŒ‰âˆ’1ğ‘›31\lceil\frac{n}{3}\rceil-1 for Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Observe that these SA protocolsÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) are the most influential and practical-oriented solutions in the field.

More formally, in each round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN, the active users ğ’°(t)superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} do not send their model updates {Î”ğ’Ÿi(t)Î˜(t)}uiâˆˆğ’°(t)subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptÎ”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡\{\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\}_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}} in the clear. Instead, they execute the SA protocol Î Î \Pi to securely compute the aggregation v=âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°(t)Î”ğ’Ÿi(t)Î˜(t)ğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptÎ”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–v=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}}\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} (seeÂ SectionÂ 3.3) for at least qğ‘q users. Only the final aggregation vğ‘£v is revealed to the serverÂ Sğ‘†S. More importantly, we do not target any specific implementation of SA. In fact, our attack exploits a vulnerability caused by the incorrect usage of SA in the FL protocol. In particular, the FL protocol does not validate the inputs of SA (i.e., model updates). For this reason, to keep the attack general, we replace the execution of the underlying SA protocol with the invocation of its ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}} (SectionÂ 3.3).

We model an adversarial server Sğ‘†S whose objective is to learn information about the local dataset ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of one (or more) target user uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} that participates in the execution of the protocol, outside what can be learned from the aggregated model updates. Sğ‘†S can deviates from a honest execution (e.g., it sends arbitrary messages) as defined inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Section 6.2) andÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020, Section 4). Specifically, in our attacks, the malicious server Sğ‘†S exploits the model inconsistency attack vector; that is, Sğ‘†S provides arbitrary malicious parameters to arbitrary users even within the same training round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN. Although the adversarial server Sğ‘†S is allowed to collude with at most mğ‘šm users (as considered byÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020)), our attacks demonstrate that SA is ineffective in FL even when m=0ğ‘š0m\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu0, i.e., the server is malicious, but it does not collude with any user.777However, collusion with users improves the effectiveness of the attacks when additional mechanisms such as distributed differential privacy are in place. This ensures the effectiveness of the proposed attacks also outside the cross-device FL setting, where the parameter server does not perform user sub-sampling.

Lastly, we assume the standard, centralized, communication topology of FL as in real-world applicationsÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2019; Yang etÂ al., 2018), where each user is authenticated by a PKI and shares an encrypted channel with the serverÂ Sğ‘†S. The SA protocols inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) are designed for this communication topology. Moreover, note that a PKI is a necessary assumption. Indeed, as described inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Section 6.2) andÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020, Section 4.2), without a PKI, a server could break the privacy of users by simply launching a sybil attack. Assuming the existence of a PKI is enough to rule out such trivial sybil attacksÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Section 6.2) andÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020, Section 4.2).

5. Gradient suppression attack

In this section, we present our first attack, dubbed gradient suppression, in which a malicious server exploits the model inconsistency attack vector to bypass SA and leak the model update of a chosen target user.

In a nutshell, the malicious server Sğ‘†S selects a target user uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} among the set of active users ğ’°(t)superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} of the current round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN. The aim of Sğ‘†S is then to preserve the targetâ€™s model update during the SA process by tampering with the parameters for the other non-target users. Here, Sğ‘†S creates a set of malicious parametersÂ Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} that is sent to the non-target users ğ’°(t)âˆ–{uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—}superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} whereas uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} receives the real parameters vector Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)}. The malicious Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} is crafted in such a way that the local application of gradient descent performed by a non-target users produces a tampered model update Î”ğ’Ÿi(t)Î˜~subscriptsuperscriptÎ”~Î˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}. Once that the targetâ€™s model update is on the server-side, Sğ‘†S can leak sensitive information about the batch ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}, used during the current round tğ‘¡t of FL by executing an arbitrary gradient inversion attack (see SectionÂ 2.2) or related inference attacks.

Given the fact that the SA performs the sum among the usersâ€™ model updates, the simplest way to achieve the isolation of the targetâ€™s signal is to force the tampered model updates to have a negligible magnitude, or, more strictly, to be zero everywhere. Next, we show how to compute the malicious parameters Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} required to perform the gradient suppression attack. We focus on the most widely adopted class of deep learning modelsâ€”the one based on the ReLUÂ activation function. However, in AppendixÂ C, we show that our approach extends to arbitrarily composed architectures.

5.1. Gradient suppression for ReLUÂ layers: The dead-layer trick

The Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) activation function:

(6) Râ€‹eâ€‹Lâ€‹Uâ€‹(x)={xifÂ â€‹x>00ifÂ â€‹xâ‰¤0ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘¥casesğ‘¥ifÂ ğ‘¥00ifÂ ğ‘¥0ReLU(x)=\begin{cases}x&\text{if }x>0\\ 0&\text{if }x\leq 0\end{cases}

is one of the core technical improvements that led to deep learningÂ (Nair and Hinton, 2010). Nowadays, this function is ubiquitous in computer vision architectures, representing the core building block of highly successful and standardized models such as ResNetÂ (He etÂ al., 2016), DenseNetÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2017) and many others. Outside the computer vision domain, the ReLUÂ activation function is currently finding its place in Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications thanks to the success of transformer networksÂ (Vaswani etÂ al., 2017; Radford etÂ al., 2019; Brown etÂ al., 2020).

The dying-ReLU problemÂ (Lu, 2020) is a phenomenon that naturally occurs during the training of deep neural networks that rely on the ReLUÂ activation function. When a layer â„“â„“\ell â€œdiesâ€, it enters a state where it can only produce a constant output. More importantly, the dead layer â„“â„“\ell cannot produce any gradient during the gradient descent iterations, i.e., the derivatives of its trainable parameters are zero regardless of the given input and loss function.

Despite the dying-ReLU phenomenon can naturally occur, we show that it can also be intentionally induced by a malicious server to prevent a network from producing a gradient for one or more sets of parameters. Next, we describe how this can be achieved and exploited to perform our gradient suppression attack.

5.1.1. Triggering the Dying-ReLU phenomenon with malicious parameters

The Dying-ReLU phenomenon is due to the piece-wise non-differentiability of the ReLUÂ activation function. Consider a neural layer â„“â„“\ell with a Râ€‹eâ€‹Lâ€‹Uğ‘…ğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘ˆReLU activation function, i.e., â„“â€‹(x)=Râ€‹eâ€‹Lâ€‹Uâ€‹(xâŠ—Î¸+b)â„“ğ‘¥ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘ˆtensor-productğ‘¥ğœƒğ‘\ell(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5muReLU(x\otimes\theta+b). FromÂ EquationÂ 6, we can see that the ReLUÂ function behaves as a constant function Râ€‹eâ€‹Lâ€‹Uâ€‹(x)=0ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘¥0ReLU(x)=0, whenever the input xğ‘¥x is equal or less than zero. Since the derivative of a constant function is always 00, we can easily conclude that, for any loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}, then we have âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚Î¸=[0]â„’ğœƒdelimited-[]0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta}=[0] and âˆ‚â„’âˆ‚b=[0]â„’ğ‘delimited-[]0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b}=[0] when xâŠ—Î¸+bâ‰¤0tensor-productğ‘¥ğœƒğ‘0x\otimes\theta+b\leq 0. In other words, the layer â„“â„“\ell receives zero gradient for its trainable parameters Î¸,bâˆˆÎ˜ğœƒğ‘Î˜\theta,b\in\Theta every time its pre-activation (i.e.,Â xâŠ—Î¸+btensor-productğ‘¥ğœƒğ‘x\otimes\theta+b) is less or equal to zero.

A malicious server Sğ‘†S can exploit the above behavior of theÂ ReLUÂ function to kill a layer â„“â„“\ell of a neural networkÂ fğ‘“f, i.e., by forcing the pre-activation xâŠ—Î¸+btensor-productğ‘¥ğœƒğ‘x\otimes\theta+b of â„“â„“\ell to be less or equal to zero. This can be accomplished (without control over the input xğ‘¥x of an user) by computing some malicious trainable parameters Î¸~,b~âˆˆÎ˜~~ğœƒ~ğ‘~Î˜\widetilde{\theta},\widetilde{b}\in\widetilde{\Theta} of the layer â„“â„“\ell.

In more detail, the operator âŠ—tensor-product\otimes (see SectionÂ 3.1) is generally based on a multiplication-like operation between the input xğ‘¥x and the kernel Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Therefore, we can easily force the pre-activation to be [0]delimited-[]0[0] for any inputÂ xğ‘¥x by just choosing Î¸~=[0]~ğœƒdelimited-[]0\widetilde{\theta}=[0] and b~=[â„â‰¤0]~ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptâ„absent0\widetilde{b}=[\mathbb{R}_{\leq 0}]. Alternatively, having some knowledge on the inputÂ xğ‘¥x, we can rely on different setups for Î¸~~ğœƒ\widetilde{\theta} and b~~ğ‘\widetilde{b}. For instance, if xğ‘¥x is strictly positive (e.g.,Â becauseÂ xğ‘¥x is the output produced by a previous ReLU-layer or because of the adopted input normalization process), it is enough to produce a malicious Î¸~~ğœƒ\widetilde{\theta} with negative numbers. Instead, if a bound on xğ‘¥x is known (e.g.,Â xâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğ‘¥11x\in[-1,1]), we can just set the malicious bias vector b~~ğ‘\widetilde{b} to a large enough negative number (e.g., fix Î¸~~ğœƒ\widetilde{\theta} and set b~=âˆ’mâ€‹aâ€‹xâ€‹(Î¸~â€‹â¨‚x)~ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥~ğœƒtensor-productğ‘¥\widetilde{b}=-max(\widetilde{\theta}\bigotimes x)).

Now, an attacker can exploit the dead-layer trick to force a ReLU-based network to produce zero gradient for every layer. In this direction, it is important to note that, for plain, ReLU-based feedforward architectures, the server Sğ‘†S can just kill the kernels in the very first layer to suppress the gradient flow for the rest of the network.888However, if present, all the bias terms of the network should be set to values â‰¤0absent0\leq 0. Hence, killing all the kernels {Î¸i}subscriptğœƒğ‘–\{\theta_{i}\} in the original parametersÂ Î˜Î˜\Theta is very often not necessary. Similarly, in modern architectures, neural layers tend to be arranged in the form:

neural layerâ†’normalization layerâ†’activation.â†’neural layernormalization layerâ†’activation\text{neural layer}\rightarrow\text{normalization layer}\rightarrow\text{activation}.

Therefore, to suppress the gradient for the network, it is enough to zero only the parameters of the normalization layers as these are often defined as Î³â€‹x^+Î²ğ›¾^ğ‘¥ğ›½\gamma\hat{x}+\beta, where x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} is the normalized input. For instance, in the case of batch normalization, the attacker can kill the neural layer by setting the vectors Î³ğ›¾{\gamma} and Î²ğ›½{\beta} of the batch normalization to [0]delimited-[]0[0]. Nevertheless, the strategy would work for every architectural configuration.

Moreover, even if ReLUÂ is the most common activation function in deep learning, a server Sğ‘†S can always maliciously choose a neural network architecture fğ‘“f that presents a ReLUÂ activation function in the â€œright spotsâ€ of the model without requiring unrealistic architecture modifications. The only gradient signal that cannot be recovered by the server using the dead-ReLUÂ trick is the one of the bias term of the last layer (details are given in AppendixÂ C). This follows from the fact that the terminal layer of a network only rarely exhibits a ReLUÂ activation function. A trivial solution for the malicious server is to avoid the bias term of the last layer when defining the architecture of the model. Alternatively, the malicious server can ignore the gradient of the bias term during the gradient inversion. Indeed, this represents only a tiny portion of the total number of trainable parameters of the network. For instance, in the case of a ResNet50 trained on ImageNetÂ (He etÂ al., 2016), the bias vector in the final layer counts for only 4â‹…10âˆ’5%â‹…4percentsuperscript1054\cdot 10^{-5}\% of the total number of parameters. In Section 5.2.2, we show that gradient inversion is unaffected from this missing gradient.

5.3. Impact

Current FL+SA implementations do not prevent the gradient suppression attack, making users actively susceptible to this simple yet powerful exploit. To a certain extent, this attack can be interpreted as an invalid input validation vulnerability present in the usersâ€™ FL client software. Here, the latter permits users to perform computation on â€œsemantically malformed inputsâ€ sent by a non-trusted party, i.e., the server. This allows the server to control SAâ€™s inputs of users and eventually affect the aggregation. Furthermore, in contrast to most of the previous attacks introduced in FL, the disclosed vulnerability has the practical advantage of being completely independent of the number of users participating in the current round. Therefore, this procedure scales to millions of active users, making it applicable to real-world scenarios such as cross-device FL, which is currently being deployed in-the-wildÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2019; Yang etÂ al., 2018). In the same direction, its effectiveness is independent of the size of the model or other nuisance factors such as the stillness of usersâ€™ training datasets during the attackÂ (Lam etÂ al., 2021). Additionally, unlikeÂ (Fowl etÂ al., 2021), this attack neither hinges on auxiliary information on the usersâ€™ private sets nor requires unrealistic modifications of the model architecture; indeed, it can be applied to arbitrary architectures and loss functions. It is important to note that the gradient suppression attack can be iterated several times and arbitrarily alternated with honest training iterations. If the server wants to recover information on all the users, it has to iterate the attack several times by targeting a user at a time. Assuming no dropouts among users participating at the FL protocol, recovering the gradient of all users requires nğ‘›n iterations where nğ‘›n is the number of active users.

We stress that the gradient suppression attack shows the incorrect application of SA in FL, yielding a â€œfalse sense of securityâ€. As discussed inÂ SectionÂ 1.1, the core motivation is that SA guarantees that nothing is leaked about the model updates of the users except what can be inferred from their aggregation. This claim assumes that the inputs (i.e., model updates) of SA are fixed and are not under the control of an adversary. However, this does not hold in FL since, in this case, the value of inputs that needs to be aggregated depends on the parameters Î˜Î˜\Theta distributed by the server. Hence, a malicious server that executes the gradient suppression attack can indirectly tamper with the SAâ€™s inputs to maximize the information leaked (e.g., leak the model update of a target user).

Although the gradient suppression attack is highly effective, it can be easily detected by non-target users (we delve into this topic inÂ SectionÂ 7). Nevertheless, in the next SectionÂ 6 we introduce an extension of the gradient suppression attack that adds stealthiness and it is harder to detect. More generally, one can always trade effectiveness for stealthiness also in the gradient suppression framework. For instance, if recovering noisy model updates is acceptable, the server can send highly optimized models (e.g.,Â obtained after some rounds of honest execution) to non-targets and an unoptimized model to the target. Intuitively, the gradient from the unoptimized model should dominate the aggregation given the low magnitude and sparsity of the one produced by the optimized models (see FigureÂ 4).

6. Canary-gradient attack for property inference

SectionÂ 5 demonstrates that a malicious server Sğ‘†S can force non-target users to produce a zero gradient during a round of FL. This allows Sğ‘†S to bypass SA and, at the same time, maximize the leakage regarding the dataset of a target user. While the gradient suppression attack can be seen as the most extreme exploitation of the model inconsistency attack vector, more stealthy attacks can be created harnessing the same underlying intuition.

This section shows a general procedure that allows a malicious server to perform highly accurate property inference attacks on individual users, even if SA is enabled. The idea behind this approach is that the server can maliciously modify the parameters of the model in order to inject specific detectors in one or more subsets of the network. These detectors are specifically crafted to react to attacker-chosen trigger conditions that can be present in the usersâ€™ training instances. Whether the detector is triggered during the local training procedure, the network produces a clear footprint in the model update. Then, upon receiving the latter from a user, the server can determine if the trigger condition has been met by looking for the footprint in the model update. This allows the server to infer information on the content of the userâ€™s training set; that is, the presence or absence of data with the specific property. For instance, using this approach, the server can perform an extremely accurate membership inference on a chosen target user. Hereafter, we refer to this general procedure as the canary-gradientÂ attack.

As for the gradient suppression, the canary-gradient attack does not target any specific SA protocol but instead leverages a vulnerability of FL caused by its incorrect usage of SA. For this reason, we abstract the SA protocol with its ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}}.

6.1. The Conditional Dead-Layer trick

The main building block to construct the attack is a conditioned version of the dead-layer trick ofÂ SectionÂ 5.1. Informally, we want to â€œkillâ€ a layer only if the instance xâˆˆğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of the target uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} satisfies a particular condition. In other words, we would like a programmed death through the backdooring of the layer. For the sake of presentation, we introduce the conditional dead-layer trick assuming that SA is disabled. Then, inÂ SectionÂ 6.2 we extend the discussion to the case of SA enabled.

Formally, given a layer â„“â„“\ell, we want to find some malicious parameters Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} to enforce the following behavior

(11) âˆ‚â„’â€‹(ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t),Î˜~)âˆ‚Î¾â‰ 0âŸºâˆƒxâˆˆğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t):Pâ€‹(x)=ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾,âŸºâ„’subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—~Î˜ğœ‰0ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—:ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}},\widetilde{\Theta})}{\partial\xi}\neq 0\Longleftrightarrow\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{True},

As discussed in SectionÂ 5, suppressing the gradient for a set of parameters in a ReLU-based layer is about controlling the value of its pre-activation. Therefore, given a neural layer â„“â„“\ell with ReLUÂ activation, we can substituteÂ EquationÂ 11 with:

(12) â„“Î¾=(xÎ¾âŠ—Î¸Î¾+bÎ¾)>0âŸºâˆƒxâˆˆğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t):Pâ€‹(x)=ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾,âŸºsubscriptâ„“ğœ‰tensor-productsubscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰subscriptğœƒğœ‰subscriptğ‘ğœ‰0ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—:ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾\ell_{\xi}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu(x_{\xi}\otimes\theta_{\xi}+b_{\xi})>0\Longleftrightarrow\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{True},

where Î¾={Î¸Î¾,bÎ¾}ğœ‰subscriptğœƒğœ‰subscriptğ‘ğœ‰\xi=\{\theta_{\xi},b_{\xi}\}, and xÎ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰x_{\xi} is the subset of the input ofÂ â„“â„“\ell that interacts with the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi and â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} refers to the subset of the output of the layerÂ â„“â„“\ell computed using the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi.

The simplest and most natural way to find Î¾ğœ‰\xi that correctly induceÂ EquationÂ 12 is to explicitly train the layers preceding â„“â„“\ell and the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi to force â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} to produce a positive value only when the input of the network satisfies Pğ‘ƒP. In other words, we train part of the network in a classification task, using the output â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} such as the output layer, where the classification threshold is centered in zero. Observe that, if the behavior ofÂ EquationÂ 12 is correctly embedded in the networkÂ fÎ˜~subscriptğ‘“~Î˜f_{\widetilde{\Theta}}, a malicious server Sğ‘†S will able to determine the event âˆƒxâˆˆğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t):Pâ€‹(x)=ğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾:ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{true} by only collecting gradient âˆ‡ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î¾subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} and check that the derivatives of Î¾ğœ‰\xi are different from zero. In SectionÂ 6.3 we show how this can be done in practice.

6.2. Targeted property inference attacks via model inconsistency

To perform the membership inference attack discussed in the previous section, the malicious server Sğ‘†S needs to have access to the gradient âˆ‡ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î¾subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This is possible when SA is disabled. On the other hand, when SA is enabled, the Sğ‘†S can inject the canary-gradient functionality in the network and then perform the inference attack on the whole pool of active users. In this scenario, Sğ‘†S would be able to infer that one of the users triggered the canary-gradient by observing that fÎ¾ğ—Œğ–ºâ€‹(âˆ‡ğ’Ÿ1(t)Î¾,â€¦,âˆ‡ğ’Ÿn(t)Î¾)=âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°(t)âˆ‡ğ’Ÿi(t)Î¾â‰ [0]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]0f^{\mathsf{sa}}_{\xi}(\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{1}},\ldots,\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{n}})=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}}\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\neq[0] where fÎ¾ğ—Œğ–ºsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºğœ‰f^{\mathsf{sa}}_{\xi} denotes the inner idealized functionality of fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}} that performs the aggregation of the gradients of Î¾ğœ‰\xi. However, in this case, the privacy of users would be partially preserved as Sğ‘†S would not be able to attribute the result of the inference attack to a specific user (â€œprivacy by shufflingâ€).

Still, we show that model inconsistency can be exploited even in this case, allowing the malicious server Sğ‘†S to bypass SA and target the specific target uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. Analogously to the gradient suppression attack (SectionÂ 5), Sğ‘†S needs to tamper with the honest parameters Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)} in order to produce two different malicious Î˜~1subscript~Î˜1\widetilde{\Theta}_{1} and Î˜~2subscript~Î˜2\widetilde{\Theta}_{2}. On the other hand, the non-target users ğ’°(t)âˆ–{uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—}superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} will receive Î˜~2subscript~Î˜2\widetilde{\Theta}_{2} that is a slight perturbation of the original model Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)} that has the additional property of unconditionally produce zero-gradient only for the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi, i.e., âˆ‡ğ’Ÿi(t)Î¾=[0]subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]0\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu[0]. This can be achieved by exploiting the dead-layer trick in a localized way. Instead of killing the gradient for the whole layer, it intentionally inhibits only the gradient produced by the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi; for instance, for just one filter in a convolution layer.

Now, when the target and non-target gradients are aggregated, the targetâ€™s gradient âˆ‡ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î¾subscriptsuperscriptâˆ‡ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} for Î¾ğœ‰\xi will be preserved, allowing the server to state the activation or non-activation of the canary-gradient, and so, with high probability, the presence of the property Pğ‘ƒP in the batch ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This intuition is captured byÂ FigureÂ 3.

Finally, given that the number of parameters in Î¾ğœ‰\xi can be arbitrarily small, the attack will leave only a minimal footprint, making the detection non-trivial (in our experiments, we show that two parameters are enough). This is also supported by the fact that the gradient becomes more sparse as the training proceeds (see FigureÂ 4), making it difficult to distinguish between natural â€œholesâ€ and artificial ones in the gradient vector.

While we gave an abstract view on the attack strategy, next, we show how the attack can be carried out on a realistic architecture such as ResNet in a membership inference attack scenario.

6.3. Injecting canary-gradient for membership inference

We show a practical example of how to model a membership attack on the training dataset of a specific user. Specifically, we target training instance xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}, and we want to infer if xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} is contained in the batch ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} used by the target user uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} to compute the gradient update in the current round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN of FL. Following previous notation, we want to infer the following property:

Pxtâ€‹(x)=ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾âŸºx=xt.âŸºsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ–³ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¾ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡P_{x_{t}}(x)=\mathsf{True}\Longleftrightarrow x=x_{t}.

We start by considering the case of FedSGD and carry out the attack on a ResNet20 network. However, for this network, we do not consider the batch normalization layers as those would make the attack trivial. Indeed, if batch normalization is used, we could detect the activation of â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} by checking the average computed and sent to the server to update the running mean. For this reason, we keep the attack general by substituting every batch normalization with layer normalizationÂ (Ba etÂ al., 2016) that does not present this issue and has an overlapping role. We then extend the attack to FedAVG in AppendixÂ D.

In our experiment, we inject the canary gradient in the last residual block of the network. This is because the terminal layers are usually the ones that receive the sparsest gradient during the training. Since the normalization layer precedes the ReLUÂ activation function, we chose a subset of the parameters of the latter as our Î¾ğœ‰\xi. In particular, we can pick any pair (Î³i,Î²i)subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ›½ğ‘–(\gamma_{i},\beta_{i}) in the scale and shift vectors Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î²ğ›½\beta. Thus, in this case, Î¾ğœ‰\xi is composed of only two parameters, that is about 7â‹…10âˆ’4%â‹…7percentsuperscript1047\cdot 10^{-4}\% of the total number of parameters in the network. Hereafter, we always choose i=0ğ‘–0i=0; however, choosing a different channel would not affect the attack.

To inject the canary gradient, we use a learning-based approach. In this direction, we assume that the adversary (i.e., malicious server) knows a shadow dataset ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s} defined in the same domain of the target point xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}. For instance, if xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} is a face image, ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s} contains face images as well. We stress that, as we will show later, the distribution of ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s} and one of the usersâ€™ datasets can be different. Intuitively, the role of ğ’Ÿssubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ \mathcal{D}_{s} is providing negative samples while training â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} to fire on xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}. It is important to note that the canary-gradient attack is agnostic, and the simple training procedure discussed can be substituted with other techniques. For instance, approaches such asÂ (Fowl etÂ al., 2021) and learning-based approaches that do not require negative samples (i.e.,Â one-class classification) may be used to reach the same result. In this direction, our main contribution is introducing the idea that the server can manipulate the derivative of the current model to encode arbitrary messages (and that these messages can be retrieved under SA).

We can now inject the canary gradient by reducing the malicious injection to a classification problem. We train the split of the network up to Î¾ğœ‰\xi in producing positive â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} when the networkâ€™s input contains xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}. In our case, with Î¾={Î³i,Î²i}ğœ‰subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ›½ğ‘–\xi=\{\gamma_{i},\beta_{i}\}, we have â„“Î¾=Î³iâ€‹xiÂ¯+Î²isubscriptâ„“ğœ‰subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–Â¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ›½ğ‘–\ell_{\xi}=\gamma_{i}\bar{x_{i}}+\beta_{i}, where xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\bar{x} is the normalized input of the layer. Our loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} for a batch of size nğ‘›n is simply defined as the binary cross entropy:

(13) âˆ’1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n{Î±1â‹…logâ¡(sigmoidâ€‹(â„“Î¾))ifÂ â€‹x=xtÎ±0â‹…logâ¡(1âˆ’sigmoidâ€‹(â„“Î¾))otherwise,1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›casesâ‹…subscriptğ›¼1sigmoidsubscriptâ„“ğœ‰ifÂ ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ›¼01sigmoidsubscriptâ„“ğœ‰otherwise-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\begin{cases}\alpha_{1}\cdot\log(\texttt{sigmoid}(\ell_{\xi}))&\text{if }x=x_{t}\\ \alpha_{0}\cdot\log(1-\texttt{sigmoid}(\ell_{\xi}))&\text{otherwise}\end{cases},

where instances different from xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} are sampled from Dssubscriptğ·ğ‘ D_{s}, and Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1} and Î±0subscriptğ›¼0\alpha_{0} weight the loss for the two events. In other words, we want to â€œoverfitâ€ the network to produce positiveÂ â„“Î¾subscriptâ„“ğœ‰\ell_{\xi} only for the pointÂ xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}, while squashing underÂ 00 the feature-space around it. This intuition is depicted in FigureÂ 5. We stop the training when we reach a training loss lower than a given threshold.

Finally, the gradient for Î¾ğœ‰\xi in the non-target users is unconditionally suppressed by just setting both Î³i=Î²i=0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ›½ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}=\beta_{i}=0, but other configurations are possible.

6.3.1. Results

We evaluated the effectiveness of our attack. We test three different image datasets, namely, CIFAR10, CIFAR100Â (Krizhevsky, 2009), and TinyImagenetÂ (Chrabaszcz etÂ al., 2017). We use all the possible permutations of those datasets to represent the private and shadow distribution for the canary-gradient attack, obtaining 666 different configurations.

To run the experiments, we pick xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} (i.e.,Â the target of the membership inference) at random from the validation set of the private dataset. Then, we trained the model by injecting the canary-gradient in the channel 00 of the last normalization layer in the last residual block. After the injection, we evaluated the canaryâ€™s effectiveness by testing that the canary-gradient is non-zero when xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} is in the training batch and zero otherwise. To this end, we iterate over all the training data of the private dataset by selecting a batch ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} of size nğ‘›n at a time. Given ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, we compute the gradient according to the original loss function and test that Î¾ğœ‰\xi has gradient zero (precision). Then, we insert xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, and we test if the gradient of Î¾ğœ‰\xi is different from zero (recall). We perform the test on the three private datasets with different batch sizes and repeat the test for 505050 different xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} for every case.We report our results inÂ FigureÂ 6, where we use the notation â€œprivate-datasetâ†â†\leftarrowshadow-datasetâ€.

The canary gradient has perfect recall (i.e.,Â if xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} is in the batch, the canary is always triggered), but it can be subject to false-positive errors with low probability. The global accuracy of the method is about 99%percent9999\% for a batch size up to 128128128. The precision of the attacks slowly decreases when the batch size becomes larger. This follows from the fact that larger batches have more probability of including at least one â€œfalse trigger exampleâ€ that causes a false positive. Intuitively, false positives are instances that induce a feature representation that is similar to the target one; a few examples are given in FigureÂ 7. Therefore, while false triggers reduce the accuracy of the attack, these can still inform the attacker that instances similar to xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} are present in the victimâ€™s local training set. The attacker can intentionally tune the definition of similarity by introducing the desired inductive bias in the canary injection process.999For instance, the server can train the canary to intentionally react only to â€œred carsâ€, by training it accordingly. Regardless of the presence of false triggers, the attack is appreciably precise; the accuracy remains higher than 96%percent9696\% even in the worst configuration. The canary-gradient attack also applies to FedAVG by just requiring minimal effort to the malicious parameter server. In AppendixÂ D, we empirically demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach.

6.4. Impact

Although we presented the canary-gradient attack to execute a membership inference, the same approach can be applied to any type of property inference. Ideally, it is sufficient to define a different trigger condition and train the network accordingly. Moreover, the server can inject multiple canary-gradient with different triggers in the same network and infer non-binary properties. In the same direction, the server can simultaneously perform inference on multiple users without losing accuracy by carefully managing the allocation of conditional and unconditional dead-layers.

More importantly, the canary-gradient attack maintains the same practical properties as the gradient-suppression attack; mainly, it requires only a training round to perform, its effectiveness is independent of the number of users participating in the round, and it is loss agnostic (i.e.,Â it works for any learning task). However, unlike the gradient suppression approach, this leaves only a minimal footprint in the model updates. Note that the canary gradient can be injected while training the model on the original task, and so minimizing the utility loss of the target model. On the other hand, suppressing a limited number of parameters in the non-target models (e.g.,Â two in our example) has only a negligible impact on the utility.101010This is equivalent to perform dropoutÂ (Srivastava etÂ al., 2014) on a single channel on a single layer in the network.

This attack demonstrates that a malicious server can perform highly accurate property inference attacks on individual users even if SA is adopted from the latter. Again, the introduced training-based approach is just an example, and more sophisticated techniques may be devised to reach the same (or better) results by relying on the same general construction.

For completeness, we emphasize that, even in the case of canary-gradient attacks, the discussion about the insecurity of the combination of SA and FL applies (discussed inÂ SectionsÂ 1.1 andÂ 5.3). As for the case of gradient suppression, the canary-gradient works if the SA protocol is perfectly secure (i.e., it behaves as the ideal functionality fğ—Œğ–ºsuperscriptğ‘“ğ—Œğ–ºf^{\mathsf{sa}}).

7. Mitigations

Next, we will discuss and introduce some mitigation approaches.

The first part focuses on heuristic approaches that strive to prevent model inconsistency and attack vectors similar to those seen in this work. While they do not stop all possible attacks, their practical relevance is still significant.

Then, we analyze how combining DP with SA can lead to a more general mitigation strategy.

7.1. Heuristic mitigations against model inconsistency

SA dropout

Although the gradient suppression attack (SectionÂ 5) is effective, it can be detected easily by non-target users. Indeed, non-target users can quickly discover an ongoing attack as their models would have zero gradients throughout.111111A phenomenon that is very unlikely to be observed in reality, excluding numerical errors or pathologic overfitting. However, the target (who is the victim of the attack) cannot detect or prevent the attack without communicating with non-target users.121212Note that the standard implementation of FL does not allow users to communicate. Therefore, a solution could be instructing users not to execute the SA protocol when they detect a null gradient after a local training iteration. In this case, only the attack victims would participate in the SA protocol, which is enough to prevent the server from recovering the targetâ€™s model update. Indeed, the server would not receive enough information to unmask the target modelâ€™s update and complete the execution of SA. This is because the dropout threshold Î´ğ›¿\delta of the underlying SA protocol (i.e., the number of user dropout that the SA protocol can handle) must be set to Î´<nâˆ’1ğ›¿ğ‘›1\delta<n-1 where nğ‘›n is the number of users participating in the aggregation (otherwise, if Î´=nâˆ’1ğ›¿ğ‘›1\delta=n-1, a malicious user can unmask the gradients of other users). SeeÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) for more details. Nevertheless, this detection strategy does not work in the case of the canary-gradient attack (SectionÂ 6). The â€œnegligibleâ€ footprint of the model update does not allow for a reliable detection since sparse model updates are common in an honest execution of FL (seeÂ FigureÂ 4).

Parameter validation using signatures

Another approach consists of checking that all users have received the same parameters Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)} in the current round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN of FL. For example, each uiâˆˆğ’°(t)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)} sends the parameters Î˜i(t)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–\Theta^{(t)}_{i} (or its hash) sent by Sğ‘†S to all other users. Then, each uiâˆˆğ’°(t)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)} checks that

(14) Î˜i(t)=Î˜j(t)â€‹Â for everyÂ â€‹ui,ujâˆˆğ’°(t).formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘—Â for everyÂ subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)}_{i}=\Theta^{(t)}_{j}\text{ for every }u_{i},u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}.

If the check fails, the user aborts. It is easy to see that this strategy does not allow Sğ‘†S to execute model inconsistency attacks (note that it can still send a malicious parameters Î˜~~Î˜\widetilde{\Theta} to all). Unfortunately, in the standard communication topology of FL (seeÂ SectionÂ 4), users do not have a direct communication channel. Each message needs to go through the server that, in turn, will forward the message to the intended receiver. Hence, a malicious server can perform a man-in-the-middle attack and substitute each Î˜i(t)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–\Theta^{(t)}_{i} sent by uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} with an arbitrary honest-looking parameters Î˜Î˜\Theta. If we want to preserve the communication topology of FL, digital signatures must be involved. For example, assuming that each uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} holds a key pair (sâ€‹ki,pâ€‹ki)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–(sk_{i},pk_{i}) then uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} needs to (i)ğ‘–(i) sign its message before sending it to the server Sğ‘†S and, (iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–(ii) verify the signature (using the public key pâ€‹kjğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—pk_{j} of the signee) of each message received. If the security of the signature holds, then the server can not change the messages of users. As a consequence, users are guaranteed that the message is honest, and they can perform the check defined inÂ EquationÂ 14. We stress that this approach works under the assumption that users ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U} can trust and know (in advance) the public keys of all other users (e.g., there is a trusted certification authority). Note that this assumption is at the root of the SA protocols of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020).

This approach would add one round of communication without modifying the implementation of the underlying SA protocol. However, this round could be merged with the ones of SA, e.g., the third round of the SA protocol of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017, Figure 2). Regarding the communication complexity, exchanging the signatures of the received parameters increases communication by nâ‹…â„“â‹…ğ‘›â„“n\cdot\ell where nğ‘›n is the number of active users and â„“â„“\ell is the size of one signature (e.g., 256256256 bits).

Conditional secure aggregation

Another mitigation consists of building a modified SA version for FL that performs the aggregation only if a particular condition Cğ¶C is satisfied. Otherwise, it outputs a random value (or fixed value âŠ¥bottom\bot denoting that the aggregation did not occur). Intuitively, by setting the condition Cğ¶C toÂ EquationÂ 14, the FL protocol executes the aggregation (and continue its execution) only if all the users have received the same parameters Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)} in the current round tâˆˆ\NNğ‘¡\NNt\in\NN. This would hinder a malicious server Sğ‘†S from exploiting the model inconsistency attack vector. Naturally, such a protocol can be built leveraging general MPC techniques. However, this would yield an inefficient aggregation that will not be deployed in practice. A candidate practical implementation of this SA for the specialized condition ofÂ EquationÂ 14 can be easily obtained by modifying the SA protocol of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Still, we stress that this approach can also be applied to the SA protocol of Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020). In a nutshell, inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) (andÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020)) there is an ordering over the users ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U} and each pair (ui,uj)subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—(u_{i},u_{j}) such that uiâ‰ ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{i}\neq u_{j} share a random secret si,jsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—s_{i,j}. During the aggregation, each user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} masks its input visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} in the following way:

yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\displaystyle y_{i} =vi+âˆ‘ujâˆˆğ’°:ui<ujGâ€‹(si,j)âˆ’âˆ‘ujâˆˆğ’°:ui>ujGâ€‹(sj,i)absentsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscript:subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ğ’°subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ğºsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript:subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ğ’°subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—ğºsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—ğ‘–\displaystyle=v_{i}+\sum_{u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}:u_{i}<u_{j}}G(s_{i,j})-\sum_{u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}:u_{i}>u_{j}}G(s_{j,i})

where Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) is a secure pseudorandom generator (PRG). Assuming no dropouts, the server can compute the aggregation as v=âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°vi=ğ‘£subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’°subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–absentv=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i}= âˆ‘uiâˆˆğ’°yisubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’°subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}y_{i}. To enforce the condition Cğ¶C ofÂ EquationÂ 14, we can simply substitute the PRG Gâ€‹(â‹…)ğºâ‹…G(\cdot) with the evaluation of a pseudorandom function (PRF) Fâ€‹(si,j,Î˜i(t))ğ¹subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–F(s_{i,j},\Theta^{(t)}_{i}) where Î˜i(t)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–\Theta^{(t)}_{i} are the parameters received by uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} from Sğ‘†S. It is easy to see that the aggregation remains hidden if two (or more) honest users receive two different parameters. Hence, the server Sğ‘†S can not execute a model inconsistency attack. We stress that the presented solution (as discussed inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017)) is not resilient to dropouts. Still, the same technique Â can be applied seamlessly to both SA protocols (of Bonawitz et al.Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and Bell et al.Â (Bell etÂ al., 2020)) that handle users dropouts. This second approach does not need any additional round of communication. Moreover, unlike the previous approach (i.e., parameter validation using signatures), it preserves the communication complexity of the original SA protocolsÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) since we do not need to exchange signatures between active users.

Note that SA protocols such asÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bell etÂ al., 2020) (secure in the malicious setting) already require a PKI. Hence, the proposed solutions (parameter validation using signatures and conditional secure aggregation) can be implemented by using the existing PKI of the SA protocol. Nevertheless, patching model inconsistency becomes consistently harder for variations of the vanilla FL protocol such as Asynchronous Federated LearningÂ (Nguyen etÂ al., 2021; Xu etÂ al., 2021) which is gaining substantial interest thanks to its practical advantages. For instance, in the asynchronous SA protocol proposed inÂ (So etÂ al., 2021a), solving model inconsistency would be a difficult task as aggregating model updates produced by different models is allowed by design. In these directions, solving model inconsistency efficiently remains an open problem.

7.2. Differential privacy and Secure Aggregation

One way to protect against the proposed attacks would be to mix SA with Differential Private-SGD algorithmsÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016). However, unlike previous solutions (SectionÂ 7.1), differential privacy (DP) comes with a high utility cost, especially in the context of FLÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2020). Regardless, standard central-DP approachesÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2018; Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2020) are ineffective when the parameter server is malicious. Here, the DP-noise is applied only after the model updates have been aggregated by the server. Trivially, if the server is malicious, it can just skip this step and obtain the targetâ€™s gradient in clear. Therefore, the proposed attacks remain unaffected. Peculiarly, pure central-DP is the approach used in state-of-the-art implementationsÂ (tff, 2021) and employed in real-world deployments of FLÂ (Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2020; McMahan and Abhradeep, 2022). Nonetheless, user-level differential privacy can still be efficiently obtained in the presence of a dishonest parameter server by relying on the distributed-DP modelÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2022b; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2022a) that combines (partial) local noise application and SA to securely simulate central-DP.131313Note that the server can still exploit the mğ‘šm compromised users allowed by the threat model and force them to participate in SA with zero gradient without applying the required noise. In the distributed DP model, this lets the server weaken the privacy guarantee for the target model update proportionally to mğ‘šm. More generally, as previous works have exhaustively shown it (Zhu etÂ al., 2019; Fowl etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2021; Boenisch etÂ al., 2021), the application of local noise (i.e.,Â local / distributed-DP) is sufficient to prevent gradient inversion and inference attacks on usersâ€™ model updates, and, therefore, the introduced attacks. In Appendix E, we offer a more detailed analysis of the privacy provided by the combination of SA and local-DP against the proposed attacks.

Nevertheless, the combination of SA and DPÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021; Stevens etÂ al., 2022; Chen etÂ al., 2022a, b; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021) is still partially susceptible to model inconsistency attacks since the adversary can isolate the gradient/parameters of the target user in the aggregation. That is, the server can still force the final aggregated value to be a function of the sole targetâ€™s training set. Thus, while a suitable amount of local noise still ensures the â€œprivacy by aggregationâ€ property of SA141414To be precise, it implies a consistently stronger form of privacy than â€œprivacy by aggregationâ€ alone as the model update is now also differentially private., the â€œprivacy by shufflingâ€ property remains violated. Indeed, the information leaked from the aggregated model updates can still be traced back to the targetâ€”which is known to be the only source of information in the final aggregated value.

8. Conclusion

Our research found that federated learning implementations are susceptible to a critical vulnerability caused by incorrect usage of secure aggregation. As a result, the latter does not provide any additional security to users against a malicious server (even if a trusted PKI is assumed). The primary reason for the security issue is the lack of parameter validation, which would have prevented the server from providing inconsistent views of the global parameters to users.

We emphasize that the proposed attacks are just representative examples of threats induced by model inconsistency, and that other attacks may be devised by exploiting the same general intuition. In order to protect usersâ€™ privacy from current and future attacks, we argue that federated learning implementations must account for model inconsistency and prevent it at its source.
