Appendix A Alternatives to federated learning

Aono et al.Â (Aono etÂ al., 2017) leverage a homomorphic encryption scheme to permit users to share encrypted model updates (e.g., gradients) with the server. The latter will compute the new model parameters in an encrypted fashion, using the additive homomorphic properties of the underlying encryption scheme. The new parameters remain encrypted on the server-side.

Truex et al.Â (Truex etÂ al., 2019) use a similar approach by leveraging the homomorphic properties of Paillerâ€™s cryptosystem. Here, the Pailler encryption scheme is necessary to allow the server to aggregate the model updates in an encrypted form. In contrast toÂ (Aono etÂ al., 2017), the aggregation will be decrypted by the users and made public to the server.

An analogous approach is used by EastFlyÂ (Dong etÂ al., 2020) and BatchCryptÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2020) with the main difference of keeping the aggregated updates secret to the server: The aggregation is locally decrypted by the users that will also compute the new model parameters (this differs from the original FL protocolÂ (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) in which the parameters are stored and updated by the server). In addition,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2020) proposes a batching encoding scheme (that preserves the homomorphic properties of the underlying homomorphic encryption schemes) to reduce the number of encryption operations and speed up the efficiency of the protocol.

HybridAlphaÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2019a) uses a multi-input functional encryption scheme to compute the aggregation. Informally, each user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} computes the encryption Eâ€‹nâ€‹cpâ€‹kiâ€‹(Î”ğ’ŸiÎ˜)ğ¸ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–Enc_{pk_{i}}(\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}) of its update Î”ğ’ŸiÎ˜subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}. Once the server has received all the ciphertexts, it computes the aggregation by decrypting them using the decryption key sâ€‹kfğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘“sk_{f} for the functionality fâ€‹(Î”ğ’Ÿ1Î˜,â€¦,Î”ğ’ŸnÎ˜)=âˆ‘i=1nÎ”ğ’ŸiÎ˜ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿ1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptÎ”Î˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–f(\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{1}},\ldots,\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{n}})=\sum^{n}_{i=1}\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}. Analogously, SAFElearnÂ (Fereidooni etÂ al., 2021) leverages either multi-party computation or fully homomorphic encryption to protect the individualâ€™s updates of users.

PoseidonÂ (Sav etÂ al., 2020) significantly deviates from the original FL architecture. In such a system, users are organized according to a tree hierarchy, and a multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme is used to protect usersâ€™ updates and the parameters of the neural network. At each round of the training phase, the root user sends the encrypted parameters to all users that, in turn, compute their updates according to their local training data. Then, each encrypted userâ€™s update is sent to the parent that will then aggregate all childrenâ€™s updates. At the end of this recursive process, the root receives the encrypted aggregation (that contains the updates of all users) and will update the parameters. The entire computation of the training process is executed inside the multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme. This permits them to keep the updates and the parameters encrypted. The latter remains encrypted even after the training process, and the model evaluation requires further computation inside the multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme. Note that PoseidonÂ (Sav etÂ al., 2020) is an extension of SPINDLEÂ (Froelicher etÂ al., 2021). The former handles complex machine learning models (such as neural networks), while the latter supports only generalized linear models.

Lastly, we mention CerebroÂ (Zheng etÂ al., 2021) that proposes a compiler to automatically transform Python-like domain-specific language into an optimized MPC protocol for collaborative learning allowing users to keep their plaintext data secret. We stress that CerebroÂ (Zheng etÂ al., 2021) does not relate in any way with FLÂ (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) and it must be interpreted as an alternative to FL.

Attack applicability

As discussed in SectionÂ 4, our attacks are general and equally effective independently from the SA protocol used. This because they exploit a vulnerability of FL caused by the incorrect usage of SA. More precisely, our main attack applies to all the FL/SA protocols that do not prevent the parameter server from deviating from the honest execution. This class also includes most of the schemes that rely on fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) e.g.,Â Â (Fereidooni etÂ al., 2021). The reason is that FHE would still allow the server to multiply the individual encrypted parameters by the constant 00 and produce 00 gradient everywhere when used by the non-target users (see AppendixÂ C). The only requirement is that server is required to collude with a least one user in order to access the result of the attack (the target model update) once decrypted by the pool (e.g.,Â m>0ğ‘š0m>0).

Protocols based on Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) can stop the server from executing malicious codeÂ (Mo etÂ al., 2021; Hashemi etÂ al., 2021). Thus, a properly deployed TEE environment with ideal/perfect hardware and secure and authenticated communication would prevent all the active attacks currently in the literatureÂ (Fowl etÂ al., 2021; Lam etÂ al., 2021; Boenisch etÂ al., 2021), including ours. However, the reality is that trusted hardware is vulnerable to side-channel attacks, and there is significant performance degradation when extending side-channel protections to arbitrary computations. Therefore, it remains unclear whether side-channel attacks can be entirely eliminated.

Ideal world

In the ideal world, the protocol execution is replaced by a trusted third party that honestly computes fğ‘“f. In more detail, each user uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} sends its input xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} to the third party. Security

At a high level, the security of Ï€ğœ‹\pi is defined by comparing the ideal and real world. In particular, Ï€ğœ‹\pi is secure if there exists a simulator Sğ‘†S that simulates the view of a real-world adversary Ağ´A by leveraging the interactions performed in the ideal world. This implies that any attack in the real world â€œcorrespondsâ€ to an attack in the ideal world that, in turn, provides the maximum security guarantees that can be achieved. In other words, a secure protocol Ï€ğœ‹\pi provides at least the same level of security as if we had an honest, trusted party computing fğ‘“f without exposing to an adversary the inputs of uncorrupted users.

Appendix C Gradient suppression for arbitrary architectures

In SectionÂ 5 we focused on ReLU-based layers as these are instrumental for our second attack (SectionÂ 6). Nevertheless, gradient suppression can be achieved for networks composed of arbitrary activation functions at the cost of flexibility and granularity. Intuitively, we can force any differentiable function to unconditionally produce a zero gradient by constraining it to become constant with respect to the differentiated terms. In the context of neural networks, this means making the loss function constant with respect to the trainable parameters of the network. Formally, given a neural network fÎ˜(t)subscriptğ‘“superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡f_{\Theta^{(t)}} and a loss function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}, this can be achieved by bringing Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)} in a state such that:

(15) âˆ€x,y,â„’â€‹(y,fÎ˜(t+1)â€‹(x))=c,for-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦â„’ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡1ğ‘¥ğ‘\forall x,y,\ \mathcal{L}(y,f_{\Theta^{(t+1)}}(x))=c,

where cğ‘c is an arbitrary constant and Î˜(t+1)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡1\Theta^{(t+1)} represents any possible alteration of the parameters of the network achievable starting from Î˜(t)superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡\Theta^{(t)}. Intuitively, when in this state, the parameters of the network have zero gradient since their alteration does not affect the loss function.

Bringing an arbitrary architecture in the state described inÂ EquationÂ 15 is trivial, and, for standard feedforward networks, this requires to act only on the kernels of the last and penultimate layer. Hereafter, we refer to the composition of these last two layers as Ï•lâ€‹(Ï•pâ€‹(aâŠ—Î¸p+bp)âŠ—Î¸l+bl)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘™tensor-productsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘tensor-productğ‘subscriptğœƒğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğœƒğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘™\phi_{l}(\phi_{p}(a\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p})\otimes\theta_{l}+b_{l}) where Ï•lsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘™\phi_{l} and Ï•psubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘\phi_{p} are the two arbitrary activation functions for the last and penultimate layer respectively andÂ ağ‘a represents the intermediate state of the network up to the penultimate layer.

Appendix D Canary-gradient on FedAVG

At least theoretically, extending the canary-gradient attack presented inÂ SectionÂ 6 to the FedAVG protocol can be problematic. In FedAVG, a user locally applies multiple iterations of SGD, modifying the parameters of the model. Thus, there is the possibility that the user overwrites the canary functionality during the process. However, this can be easily prevented by the server. Indeed, given the stateless nature of users in FL, the parameter server must distribute the hyper-parameters needed for the training process. In this direction, the server takes care of the learning rate. Therefore, the server can simply select a low learning rate to preserve the canaryâ€™s functionality. The rationale here is that the perturbation of the local parameters induced by the local training steps is proportional to the learning rate. A low learning rate ensures to the server a bounded modification of the local parameters and, so, a limited perturbation of the hidden canary functionality originally injected in the model. Instead, the partial dead-kernel in the non-targetâ€™s model cannot be revived regardless of the number of iterations and the given learning rate.

In practice, even setting a standard learning rate such as 0.0010.0010.001 (which is quite common, especially towards the end of the training) seems enough to preserve the canary functionality during the local learning iterations. This is shown inÂ FigureÂ 9(a), where the canary functionality is tested after an increasing number of local training steps. We rely on the same setup ofÂ SectionÂ 6.3.1, and we use a batch size of 646464. As it can be observed, the accuracy of the attack does naturally decrease with the increase in the number of iterations. However, this performance loss is limited, and the accuracy always remains in theÂ 97%percent9797\%-range even in the worst case. Nevertheless, there is a trade-off between effectiveness and stealthiness of the attack, and such a performance loss can be further reduced by considering a lower learning rate. This is shown inÂ FigureÂ 9(b), for a learning rate of 0.00050.00050.0005. In this case, we do not need model inconsistency, and the server can send the same hyper-parameters (learning rate) to all the users in the pool without distinction.

Once computed the output of the secure aggregation, the server can state if the canary has been triggered by cheeking if Î¾tâ‰ Î¾t+1subscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡1\xi_{t}\neq\xi_{t+1}. Intuitively, the parameters Î¾ğœ‰\xi are modified if and only if the target user produced a non-zero gradient for Î¾ğœ‰\xi during the training at least once (i.e.,Â the trigger condition has been met).

Appendix E A Note on the combination of SA with Local Differential Privacy as a Defense

When SA is combined with local-DP, the amount of noise applied to the model update recovered by our attacks is proportional to the number of users participating in the round.

In the local-DP setting without SA, the model update of the user uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} accessible by the parameter server is:

Î”^ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î˜(t)+ğ”‘Ïµ,subscriptsuperscript^Î”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ”‘italic-Ïµ\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon},

where ğ”‘Ïµsubscriptğ”‘italic-Ïµ\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon} is the local noise applied by uğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ‘¢ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—u_{\mathsf{trgt}} to make the model updated (Ïµ)italic-Ïµ(\epsilon)-differentially-private and Î”^ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î˜(t)subscriptsuperscript^Î”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} is the clipped version of the model update. However, the situation is different when SA is combined with local-DP. In this case, assuming that all the active users ğ’°(t)superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} apply an equal amount of noise, then the attacks recover a model update defined as:

(16) Î”^ğ’Ÿğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—(t)Î˜(t)+ğ”‘Ïµ+(|ğ’°(t)|âˆ’1)â‹…ğ”‘Ïµ.subscriptsuperscript^Î”superscriptÎ˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ—ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—subscriptğ”‘italic-Ïµâ‹…superscriptğ’°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ”‘italic-Ïµ\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon}+(|\mathcal{U}^{(t)}|-1)\cdot\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon}.

As the target model update inherits the input noise added by non-target users, the amount of noise and, therefore, the degree of protection increases with the number of active users.

The privacy budget is computed withÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016) via its tensorflow-privacy implementation.

To summarize, when local-DP is combined with SA, it is possible to obtain a privacy amplification effect that is proportional to the number of non-target users. Compared to having no SA, users need to add less noise in the local-DP+SA regime to achieve the same level of protection when using a suitable trust-model.171717Other users must be honest and add the expected amount of noise.
